Title: Morning news brief
Description: Senate to vote on GOP spending bill as government shutdown deadline looms, Trump to give speech at DOJ about law and order, judges order federal agencies to reinstate thousands of fired workers.

Title: Judges order federal agencies to reinstate thousands of workers fired recently
Description: In a pair of rulings Thursday, judges ordered federal agencies to reinstate thousands of workers who were recently fired. In both cases, the judges said the mass firings appear illegal.

Title: Iranian officals meet Chinese and Russian counterparts in Beijing
Description: Iranian officials met with Chinese and Russian counterparts in Beijing on Friday to coordinate their positions on nuclear and other issues.

Title: SCOTUS-birthright citizenship
Description: The Trump administration filed three emergency applications at the U.S. Supreme Court to allow it to implement President Trump's executive order that seeks to limit birthright citizenship. In its filings Thursday, the administration asked the justices to limit the nationwide injunctions in place to the plaintiffs in the case only. This would allow the executive order to take effect otherwise.

Title: Trump administration cuts to DEI even affecting nationwide effort to plant trees
Description: The Trump administration's efforts to end diversity, equity and inclusion initiatives is hitting unexpected targets, including a major nationwide effort to plant shade trees.

Title: Federal employees union national president discusses Trump administration cuts
Description: NPR asks Everett Kelley, national president of the American Federation of Government Employees, about uncertainty for federal workers amid Trump administration cuts and a looming government shutdown.

Title: North Dakota went big for Trump. Now many farmers say they face an uncertain future
Description: North Dakota soybean farmers are anxious about another looming trade war with China. In 2018, the first Trump administration doled out billions in aid to farmers, but some say they still haven't been made whole.

Title: Big March storm system threatens U.S. with tornadoes, blizzards and wildfire risk
Description: A storm system crossing the U.S. threatens to unleash tornadoes Friday in the Mississippi Valley, blizzards in the northern Plains and dry conditions in Texas and Oklahoma that pose a wildfire risk. (Image credit: AP)

Title: Mexicans searching for missing relatives uncover possible mass killing site
Description: Distraught families from across the country have already started reaching out about clothing items they say they recognize. (Image credit: AP)

Title: The Asian elephant population in Cambodia is more robust than previously thought
Description: Some 400 to 600 Asian elephants are believed to remain living in the wild in Cambodia. Researchers said the study's findings underscore the potential of a 'national stronghold' for the species. (Image credit: The Flora & Fauna conservation/AP)

Title: A 2nd judge orders thousands of fired federal employees temporarily reinstated
Description: A federal judge in Maryland found the Trump administration acted unlawfully in firing thousands of federal employees by not first notifying states. (Image credit: Kent Nishimura)

Title: (Don't) click here to pay your tolls: How you can stop spam texts
Description: Smishing' scams aim to compromise your data and pilfer money. And if you think the problem is getting worse, you're right. (Image credit: Sean Rayford)

Title: Democratic Rep. Raúl M. Grijalva of Arizona dies at 77
Description: Democratic U.S. Rep. Raúl M. Grijalva of Arizona, who championed environmental protection during his 12 terms in Congress, died Thursday of complications from cancer treatments, his office said. (Image credit: J. Scott Applewhite)

Title: Putin says he has questions about the ceasefire with Ukraine
Description: A White House envoy is in Moscow Thursday to discuss the 30-day of proposed ceasefire with top Kremlin officials. President Vladimir Putin says Russia is open to the idea, but 'questions' remain.

Title: Doesn't make any sense': Mahmoud Khalil's lawyer on govt. efforts to deport him
Description: NPR's Ari Shapiro speaks with Mahmoud Khalil's attorney, Amy Greer, about her client's recent arrest. Khalil, a green card holder, is currently being detained by ICE officers. (Image credit: Spencer Platt)

Title: Mahmoud Khalil's lawyer talks about govt. efforts to deport her client
Description: NPR's Ari Shapiro speaks with Mahmoud Khalil's attorney, Amy Greer, about his recent arrest by ICE officers. The Trump administration has accused Khalil, a green card holder, of supporting Hamas.

Title: Israel targets what it says was an Islamic Jihad command center in Damascus
Description: An Israeli airstrike targeted a building in an upscale neighborhood, destroying an apartment that neighbors said had been vacant for years. (Image credit: Emily Garthwaite for NPR)

Title: Mass graves dug up at Gaza's al-Shifa hospital as survivors search for closure
Description: Survivors mourn those killed by Israel's military as bodies are exhumed from mass graves at Gaza's al-Shifa hospital in another reminder of war's toll.

Title: Ex-Philippine president Duterte to face trial on crimes against humanity charges
Description: Former president of the Philippines Rodrigo Duterte is in custody at the International Criminal Court. He has been under investigation since 2021 for his administration's deadly drug crackdown.

Title: What Cuts to U.S. Aid Mean in Africa
Description: President Trump has derided aid the U.S. provides overseas as rife with fraud. His administration has moved aggressively to eliminate such funding including cancelling contracts already in progress. This is all being challenged in court but the effects are being felt acutely by those providing the aid on the ground in foreign countries. We hear from three providers in Africa.

Title: As global tariff tensions rise, here's the latest on U.S. trade with top partners
Description: President Trump has upended global markets by imposing tariffs on imports from several of America's top trading partners. Here's what to know. (Image credit: Cole Burston)

Title: A man says his stepmom locked him in a room for decades. He escaped by setting a fire
Description: Police in Waterbury, Conn., allege the man's stepmother locked him in his room with limited food and water for over 20 years, until he started a fire using hand sanitizer, printer paper and a lighter. (Image credit: AP)

Title: Trump plans to visit the Justice Department Friday, a rare move for a president
Description: The president is planning to give remarks on 'restoring law and order,' according to the White House. Trump has vowed to end 'weaponization' of the DOJ after having been investigated himself. (Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

Title: Thousands of fired federal workers must be offered reinstatement, a judge rules
Description: Thousands of probationary federal employees fired by the Trump administration must be offered job reinstatement within the next week, a district judge in San Francisco has ruled, because they were terminated unlawfully. (Image credit: Alex Wroblewski)

Title: Trump's hiring freeze has halted local head counts and could threaten the U.S. census
Description: Some towns paid the U.S. Census Bureau to produce new local population counts to try to get more funding. But Trump's hiring freeze derailed their special census plans — and could hurt the 2030 count. (Image credit: Tasos Katopodis)

Title: A Putin aide rejects Trump's 30-day Ukraine ceasefire proposal
Description: As U.S. envoy Steve Witkoff enters talks in Moscow on a Trump administration proposal for a 30-day ceasefire with Ukraine, an adviser to the Russian president rejected the idea. (Image credit: Maxim Shemetov)

Title: EPA targets dozens of regulations. And, 'stranded' astronauts may return to Earth
Description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced yesterday plans to reconsider more than two dozen rules. And, astronauts 'stranded' on the International Space Station may be able to return to Earth. (Image credit: Ting Shen/AFP)

Title: What Greenland's elections mean for the island — and the U.S.
Description: This week's vote resulted in a win for pro-independence forces and a rejection of President Trump's rhetoric about annexing the island. (Image credit: Joe Raedle)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: World waits for Moscow response to ceasefire offer the U.S. brokered with Ukraine, EPA announces dozens of regulations it plans to target, Iran rebuffs Trump hopes on starting nuclear talks.

Title: DHS official defends Mahmoud Khalil arrest, but offers few details on why it happened
Description: Homeland Security deputy secretary Troy Edgar offered few details on the Trump administration's legal reasoning to deport Palestinian activist Mahmoud Khalil. (Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)

Title: DHS Deputy Secretary Troy Edgar discusses arrest of protest leader, deportations
Description: NPR speaks with Department of Homeland Security Deputy Secretary Troy Edgar about the arrest of a student protest leader and the Trump administration's ramped-up deportations of immigrants.

Title: Iran's leader rebuffs U.S. over starting nuclear program talks
Description: Iran's supreme leader rebuffed President Trump's hopes to start talks over Iran's nuclear program.

Title: President Trump's attempts to shrink government target civil rights efforts
Description: At the Labor Department, there's a draft proposal to nearly dismantle an office that investigates discrimination by federal contractors. Some fear that women and people of color will lose protections.

Title: U.S. delegation heads to Moscow after Ukraine agrees to 30-day ceasefire
Description: The U.S. resumed Ukraine military aid and intelligence sharing after Kyiv agreed to a 30-day ceasefire. Now, a U.S. delegation is heading to Moscow for talks, hoping they accept terms of the proposal.

Title: How layoffs at the Education Department might affect the agency's core functions
Description: How might layoffs at the Department of Education affect its core functions? NPR speaks with education scholar Beth Akers, a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute.

Title: Aid workers in Africa discuss the consequences of U.S. cuts to foreign aid programs
Description: NPR's Michel Martin talks about the consequences of deep cuts to foreign aid programs with three aid workers in Africa, where about a quarter of USAID funds were allocated.

Title: Rodrigo Duterte to face trial in The Hague for charges of crimes against humanity
Description: Former Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte is in custody at the International Criminal Court in The Hague, where he will face charges of crimes against humanity.

Title: What we know about the search for a U.S. student missing in the Dominican Republic
Description: Sudiksha Konanki is a Virginia resident and a student at the University of Pittsburgh. She was vacationing in Punta Cana with five others when she went missing last week. (Image credit: Francesco Spotorno)

Title: EPA announces dozens of environmental regulations it plans to target
Description: The Environmental Protection Agency didn't provide details about what it wants to do with the regulations — whether it will try to weaken them or eliminate them entirely. (Image credit: TING SHEN/AFP via Getty Images)

Title: A medieval Bishop's ring from more than 800 years ago goes to auction
Description: The ring, discovered by a metal detectorist in the U.K., is estimated to sell for between $19,000 and $23,000 at auction. (Image credit: Noonans)

Title: Judge blocks Trump from enforcing 'chilling' order against law firm
Description: While Trump's executive order takes aim at Perkins Coie, the judge said it 'casts a chilling harm of blizzard proportion across the entire legal profession.' (Image credit: Alex Wong)

Title: Louisiana is locked in a legal battle over its planned execution of a death row inmate
Description: Louisiana has hit a roadblock in its plan to resume executions after a 15-year pause. At issue is the method -- death by nitrogen gas -- an which has been used only a handful of times in Alabama and puts one religious group in particular on edge.

Title: The U.S. buys electricity from Canada. Now it's a focus of the trade war
Description: As a trade war grew this week, Ontario's leader threatened a surcharge on Canadian electricity sold in some U.S. states. The episode highlighted the U.S. reliance on imported Canadian power. (Image credit: Joe Raedle)

Title: The latest on the Trump administration's Ukraine-Russia ceasefire proposal
Description: Ukraine has agreed to a 30-day ceasefire in its war with Russia. But there's still no response from Russia to the proposal, which is being brokered by the Trump administration.

Title: Why religious leaders are divided on transgender rights
Description: When Kansas became the 26th state to ban gender-affirming medical care for teens, the Catholic Church and Southern Baptist Convention cheered the move. But not all faith leaders agree. (Image credit: Rose Conlon)

Title: Greenland votes for opposition party that favors a gradual approach to independence
Description: In a big shake up of Greenland's political landscape, a pro-business opposition party is the surprise winner in the country's election. The party favors a slow approach to gaining independence.

Title: India Sees Opportunity in U.S. Tariffs
Description: With the U.S. undertaking a tariff war with countries like China, India sees and opening. As goods from China sold in the U.S. get more expensive, India hopes to lure away manufacturers. But can they do that while avoiding being hit with U.S. tariffs themselves? We go to an Indian manufacturing hub to see what the strategy looks like.

Title: What parents, teachers and school choice groups think of Education Department cuts
Description: Teacher unions and some parent groups condemned the cuts, while school choice advocates celebrated them. (Image credit: Mark Schiefelbein)

Title: Federal judge hears challenge to Mahmoud Khalil's detention
Description: The Trump administration has accused Khalil of engaging in anti-Semitic activity and support of Hamas. The administration wants Khalil deported. But he's a legal permanent resident, and his attorneys deny any involvement with the terrorist group. (Image credit: Adrian Florido)

Title: Rodrigo Duterte is in custody in The Hague for crimes against humanity trial
Description: The former Philippine president is the first former leader from Asia to face charges at the International Criminal Court. Human rights groups say his violent crackdowns left up to 30,000 dead. (Image credit: Aaron Favila)

Title: What Trump's cuts to the Department of Education mean for schools and students
Description: The DoE is cutting staff, halting grants and pressuring schools on various administration priorities. Washington Post writer Laura Meckler discusses its destabilizing effect on the education system.

Title: Universities across the U.S. freeze hiring as federal funding hangs in the balance
Description: With uncertainties around federal funding for higher education, some schools are cutting back. Experts say that could hurt not only students and faculty, but ultimately make the U.S. less competitive. (Image credit: Mel Musto)

Title: Congress reignites a bipartisan effort to ban hair discrimination
Description: Previous attempts to pass the legislation banning hair discrimination have stalled in Congress. (Image credit: Jemal Countess)

Title: Mediators seek a new deal to release more than half of the hostages in Gaza
Description: President Trump's Mideast envoy Steve Witkoff is taking part in ceasefire talks in Qatar, the most serious Israel-Hamas talks since Trump took office. (Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

Title: Education Department's major cuts to its staff. And, a proposed Ukraine peace deal
Description: The Department of Education said it will cut around 50% of its workforce. And, the U.S. has announced it will be resuming military aid to Ukraine. (Image credit: Gent Shkullaku)

Title: America's clean-energy industry is growing despite Trump's attacks. At least for now.
Description: Clean energy is crucial to meet rising U.S. electricity demand, according to industry analysts and executives. But the Trump administration's actions could slow development. (Image credit: Rick Bowmer/AP)

Title: Taiwanese chip giant's investments in U.S. stir 'silicon shield' security worries
Description: TSMC's plan to invest $100 billion into U.S. production facilities raises concerns that its leverage in securing protection from China may be weakened. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: The European Union retaliates after the U.S. metals tariffs take hold
Description: The European Union on Wednesday announced retaliatory trade action with a series of duties on U.S. products, responding to the Trump administration rise in tariffs on all steel and aluminum imports. (Image credit: Pascal Bastien)

Title: Opposition party wins the most votes in Greenland election amid Trump takeover talk
Description: The Demokraatit Party won the most votes in Greenland's parliamentary elections, a surprise result in an election in the shadow of President Donald Trump's stated goal of taking control of the island. (Image credit: Mads Claus Rasmussen)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: U.S. resumes Ukraine military aid and intelligence sharing as Kyiv approves ceasefire, Education Department to cut nearly half of staff, House GOP spending plan to avert shutdown heads to the Senate.

Title: India hopes to bring in more manufacturers as Trump's tariffs on China take hold
Description: India hopes to benefit as President Trump seeks to shift manufacturing companies away from China. But there's an obstacle: Trump's tariffs.

Title: U.S. resumes Ukraine military aid and intelligence sharing as Kyiv approves ceasefire
Description: U.S. weapons and intelligence will flow again to Ukraine as its negotiators agreed on a 30-day ceasefire with top U.S. officials. The U.S. hopes Russia agrees to the terms of the ceasefire.

Title: Greenland votes in an election overshadowed by Trump's plans for the territory
Description: Greenland voters are choosing representatives in an election overshadowed by President Trump's assertions that he wants to make the Danish territory part of the U.S. Hear the latest results.

Title: Arizona AG urges Trump administration to halt federal firings in case to be heard Wednesday
Description: Democratic attorneys general in 19 states sued the Trump administration over its mass firing of federal workers. NPR's A Martinez talks with one of the plaintiffs, Arizona Attorney General Kris Mayes. (Image credit: Rebecca Noble)

Title: Arizona AG Kris Mayes discusses suit against Trump administration over mass firings
Description: Democratic attorneys general in 19 states sued the Trump administration over its mass firing of federal workers. NPR's A Martinez talks with one of the plaintiffs, Arizona Attorney General Kris Mayes.

Title: Following arrest of pro-Palestinian activist, White House says more arrests coming
Description: Following the arrest of student activist Mahmoud Khalil, the White House says intelligence will be used to identify individuals engaged in 'anti- American, antisemitic, pro-Hamas' activities.

Title: Why Alabama was the only state where math scores improved over pre-pandemic levels
Description: In almost every state, student achievement in math is below pre-pandemic levels. Alabama was the only state where fourth-graders' average math scores surpassed 2019. What are they doing differently?

Title: Australia won't retaliate against 'unjustified' U.S. tariffs, prime minister says
Description: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said Wednesday that U.S. tariffs on Australian steel and aluminum were unjustified, but his government would not retaliate with its own tariffs. (Image credit: Dean Lewins)

Title: Law firm says Trump order targeting it specifically is attack on rule of law
Description: Perkins Coie's lawsuit is in response to President Trump's executive order that accused the firm of 'dishonest and dangerous activity' that sought to overturn laws and elections and of allegedly discriminatory DEI policies. (Image credit: Alex Wong)

Title: Syria's Alawite sect faces violent attacks as new government tries to find its footing
Description: Syria's new government is struggling to impose order in a country where some are settling scores. Sunni Arab fighters have killed members of the same religious sect as the deposed president.

Title: Fentanyl deaths are plunging, but it's just the first step
Description: The deadliest phase of the U.S. fentanyl crisis appears to be over. That's according to new research showing fatal overdoses from fentanyl and other street drugs continue to plunge and have now dropped from their peak in all 50 states. But with that good news comes with challenges including caring for a larger population of people, who are surviving, but may be deeply unwell.For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org. Email us at considerthis@npr.org. (Image credit: Rachel Wisniewski)

Title: Ukraine accepted a U.S. proposal for a temporary ceasefire. Russia has yet to respond
Description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio says Ukraine has accepted a U.S. proposal for a ceasefire with Russia that will take effect if the Kremlin agrees.

Title: Rising Sectarian Violence In Syria
Description: In a part of Syria that had been a stronghold of deposed dictator Bashar Al-Assad, there has been a wave of violence against Alawites, the religious minority of the Assad family. Hundreds of Alawites have been killed and hundreds more have fled their homes in fear. The episode highlights the challenges the new government in Syria faces in uniting the country. But as we learn from an incident in a different Alawite community, this isn't the first episode of violence against the sect.

Title: Hundreds of Syrian children dumped in orphanages during Assad regime can't be traced
Description: An NPR investigation finds that more than 350 Syrian children were secretly placed in orphanages across the capital, Damascus, when the Assad regime was in power. Now, some of them cannot be found.

Title: Manchester United announces plans for a new $2.5 billion stadium next to Old Trafford
Description: The plans include the demolition of Old Trafford, the team's iconic 115-year-old stadium. (Image credit: Michael Regan)

Title: U.S. Education Department switches to remote work amid talk of layoffs
Description: The announcement further unsettled department employees who have spent the past several weeks anticipating sweeping staff cuts. (Image credit: Gent Shkullaku)

Title: Workers paint over the 'Black Lives Matter' street mural in D.C.
Description: Workers in Washington, D.C., have begun removing the massive street mural that defined Black Lives Matter Plaza. The city created the mural amid mass protests after police murdered George Floyd.

Title: There's a serious safety issue', investigators say following DCA mid-air collision
Description: The January mid-air collision with the Army helicopter happened as the American Airlines jet was about to land at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport. All 67 people on both aircraft died. (Image credit: Jose Luis Magana)

Title: He fled Syria's war as a teenager. He went back to help launch a tech industry
Description: Abdulwahab Omira escaped Syria's war with his family as a teenager. He recently returned as a Stanford graduate student and a budding entrepreneur, hoping to help jumpstart the country's tech industry.

Title: Greenland elections are dominated by independence and Trump's interest in the island
Description: Greenland's Prime Minister Mute Egede has framed today's vote as a 'fateful choice.' Polls show most support independence from Denmark, but the speed and timing of such a move are matters of debate. (Image credit: Joe Raedle)

Title: Green card holders' rights in spotlight after arrest of pro-Palestinian activist
Description: A New York federal judge is set to hear pivotal questions in the case of Mahmoud Khalil, a leader of large Gaza solidarity protests at Columbia University who now faces deportation after his arrest by Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents. (Image credit: Spencer Platt)

Title: Moving Palestinians out of Gaza? Trump's idea takes on a life of its own in Israel
Description: Arab countries reject Gaza displacement as ethnic cleansing, but Israeli officials say they are working on plans to make it happen, and polls suggest most Israelis are open to the idea. (Image credit: Bashar Taleb)

Title: Ukraine wants 'constructive, friendly' talks with the U.S. as they meet in Saudi Arabia
Description: Diplomatic teams from Ukraine and the United States are holding talks in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, on Tuesday in steps toward ending a full-scale war started by Russia in 2022. (Image credit: Saul Loeb)

Title: Murder the Truth' describes a campaign to silence journalists and curb free speech
Description: New York Times editor David Enrich talks about a wave of recent legal attacks on journalists — led by tech billionaires, corporations and political figures like President Trump.

Title: Stock markets fall over tariff concerns. And, fentanyl deaths drop in every state
Description: The stock market fell yesterday as investors worry that Trump's tariffs will slow the economy and possibly lead the U.S. into a recession. And, fatal fentanyl overdoses are down in every U.S. state. (Image credit: Charly Triballeau/AFP)

Title: Former Navy SEALs say they're making marine conservation cool
Description: A group called Force Blue, which does conservation work across the country, is providing what they call 'mission therapy' to veterans who miss the camaraderie and the sense of purpose of service. (Image credit: Blake Jones for NPR)

Title: The government already knows a lot about you. DOGE is trying to access all of it
Description: Agencies from Social Security to the IRS store sensitive data on millions of Americans. Here's what the government knows about us – and what's at risk as DOGE seeks access to the data. (Image credit: Greggory DiSalvo/iStock/Getty Images)

Title: In Syria, U.S.-backed Kurdish forces reach agreement with new government
Description: In Syria, there's been a major development as U.S.-backed Kurdish forces who have controlled part of the country for more than a decade have agreed to be incorporated into the Syrian state.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Ukraine and U.S. to hold talks on how to end Russia's war, stock markets slide over potential impact of Trump tariffs, federal judge temporarily halts deportation of activist arrested by ICE.

Title: Ukraine and U.S. to hold talks in Saudi Arabia on how to end Russia's war
Description: Diplomatic teams from the U.S. and Ukraine are in Saudi Arabia Tuesday to restart talks on ending the war started by Russia. Hear more on what to expect from these talks.

Title: American Bar Association president speaks out against attacks on judges and lawyers
Description: NPR's A Martinez speaks with American Bar Association President William R. Bay, who is speaking out against Trump administration attacks on judges and lawyers.

Title: Former Philippine President Duterte arrested on ICC warrant over drug killings
Description: Former Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte was arrested on order of the International Criminal Court, which has investigated mass killings during his crackdown on illegal drugs.

Title: Pentagon closing offices focused on reducing civilian casualties
Description: NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with retired U.S. Army General Joseph Votel about the Pentagon shuttering offices focused on reducing harm to civilians during U.S. combat operations.

Title: Workers have begun removing the 'Black Lives Matter' street mural in D.C.
Description: Workers in Washington, D.C., have begun removing the massive street mural that defined Black Lives Matter Plaza. The city created the mural during the mass protests after police murdered George Floyd.

Title: Workers have begun painting over the 'Black Lives Matter' street mural in D.C.
Description: Workers in Washington, D.C., have begun removing the massive street mural that defined Black Lives Matter Plaza. The city created the mural during the mass protests after police murdered George Floyd.

Title: Federal judge halts deportation of pro-Palestinian activist arrested by ICE
Description: Hear an update on Mahmoud Khalil, the former Columbia University student and protest leader arrested by ICE over the weekend. A federal judge has halted his deportation.

Title: What rights do green card holders have in the U.S.?
Description: A green card holder's arrest for his activism raises questions about the rights of legal permanent residents. NPR talks with National Foundation for American Policy Executive Director Stuart Anderson.

Title: Drought-stricken Algeria plans to import 1 million sheep ahead of Islam's Eid Al-Adha
Description: North Africa is enduring its seventh consecutive year of extreme heat and below-average rainfall. The drought has shrunk harvests and driven up the price of animal feed needed to raise livestock. (Image credit: Anis Belghoul)

Title: Former Philippine leader Duterte arrested on an ICC warrant over drug killings
Description: Former Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte was arrested Tuesday on order of the International Criminal Court in connection with a case of crime against humanity, the Philippine government said. (Image credit: Vernon Yuen)

Title: City crews have begun painting over the 'Black Lives Matter' street mural in D.C.
Description: In June 2020, the phrase 'Black Lives Matter' had been painted on the pavement by the city in uppercase, yellow letters, covering two blocks on 16th Street, about a quarter mile from the White House. (Image credit: Tyrone Turner)

Title: Arrest of pro-Palestinian protester shows escalation in Trump deportation efforts
Description: Arrest of green card holder marks escalation in Trump's efforts to deport those the administration sees as antisemitic and providing support to U.S.-designated terrorists.

Title: King Charles' new playlist includes many songs from former British colonies
Description: From disco to Afrobeats, King Charles's new Apple Music playlist features his fave tunes from former U.K. colonies. Can music heal royal rifts?

Title: Syria looks to jumpstart its tech industry
Description: One young man fled the Syrian war as a teenager. He returned as a Stanford graduate student and a budding entrepreneur, to a country trying to jumpstart its tech industry.

Title: Ukrainians describe their vision for a peace deal with Russia
Description: Ukrainians hope that officials' meeting with U.S. diplomats in Saudi Arabia will be a chance to find a framework for a ceasefire deal with Russia.

Title: Republicans say Medicaid is safe. But budget math says otherwise
Description: House Republicans have to get their spending bill passed by Friday to avoid a government shutdown. They can likely afford to lose just one vote. And that's the easy part. Then they'll have to get working on their plan to extend 4.5 trillion dollars in tax cuts passed under the Trump administration — a plan that will require huge cuts in government spending. Republicans are adamant that cuts to Medicaid are a non-starter. But the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office released a report last week that said Republicans' budget likely would require cuts to Medicaid or Medicare. (Image credit: Saul Loeb)

Title: Canada's Hudson's Bay has survived 355 years. Now the store is in crisis
Description: The department store chain, founded in 1670, can't pay its debts and says the pandemic, inflation and now trade tensions have hurt its financial future. (Image credit: Adrian Wyld/AP)

Title: Canada's Next Prime Minister; UN World Heritage Soap
Description: Mark Carney once lead the central bank of Canada and then was tapped to do the same job in England. So he knows a lot about government and finance but he has never held elected office. This weekend he was elected to be head of Canada's Liberal Party which means he'll soon be prime minister. We learn more about the man who takes the job at a time of strained relations with the U.S. And the Palestinian city of Nablus, in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, is so renowned for it's soap that the process of making it has been listed as a UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage. We go to one of the oldest soap factories there.

Title: Israeli ultranationalist lawmakers work on plan to move Palestinians out of Gaza
Description: Ultranationalist Israeli lawmakers held a parliamentary hearing to suggest ways to get Palestinians to leave Gaza, an idea raised by President Trump that is gaining public support in Israel.

Title: Media Matters sues Elon Musk's X over 'libel tourism' legal assault
Description: A new suit in an ongoing legal battle between the billionaire and the liberal advocacy group claims Musk's legal attacks are impeding the organization's work. (Image credit: Slaven Vlasic)

Title: U.S. tanker is leaking fuel in the North Sea after a collision with a container ship
Description: Jet fuel is spilling into the North Sea after a U.S.-flagged fuel tanker collided with a cargo ship off the eastern coast of England. Thirty-seven people have been brought to shore. (Image credit: Getty Images)

Title: Arrest of Palestinian protester shows escalation in Trump deportation efforts
Description: The move is an escalation in Trump's effort to increase deportations from the U.S. and strip protections from those who violate the new administration's priorities. (Image credit: Yuki Iwamura)

Title: On Harriet Tubman Day, a new effort to place the abolitionist on the $20 bill launches
Description: The latest measure, sponsored by Sen. Jeanne Shaheen, a Democrat from New Hampshire, follows years of delays and efforts to have Harriet Tubman replace President Andrew Jackson on the $20 bill. (Image credit: Harvey B. Lindsley)

Title: 5 things to know about Mark Carney, Canada's next prime minister
Description: Mark Carney is a newcomer to elected politics with decades of experience in finance. After his landslide victory, he pledged to continue tariffs on the U.S. 'until the Americans show us respect.' (Image credit: Artur Widak)

Title: Hamas is offering a truce with Israel for five to ten years, a U.S. official says
Description: President Trump's hostage affairs envoy, Adam Boehler, says a new Israel-Hamas ceasefire deal could happen 'within weeks,' as he defends his direct talks with Hamas. (Image credit: Eyad Baba)

Title: A bane for tyrants abroad, U.S.-funded networks fear fate under Kari Lake
Description: U.S.-funded international networks reach more than 420 million people in more than 100 countries each week. Some network leaders fear that Kari Lake intends to cancel all funding for them. (Image credit: Alexander Nemenov)

Title: House Republicans propose plan to avoid shutdown. And, Canada's next prime minister
Description: House Republicans unveiled a bill that has to be approved by Friday to avoid a government shutdown. And, what we know about Mark Carney, who won the leadership contest for Canada's Liberal Party. (Image credit: Zayrha Rodriguez)

Title: A single-engine plane crashes near a Pennsylvania airport, injuring 5 passengers
Description: The crash happened around 3 p.m. Sunday just south of Lancaster Airport in Manheim Township. All five victims were taken to hospitals. Nobody on the ground was hurt. (Image credit: Logan Gehman)

Title: In their own words: How COVID changed America
Description: The COVID-19 lockdown 'felt like solitary confinement,' a San Diego resident tells NPR. Even after many pandemic rules lifted, American society remains deeply fractured.

Title: Trump wants to clear homeless camps in D.C.; Mayor says his policies hurt the city
Description: NPR's Michel Martin speaks with Washington, D.C. Mayor Muriel Bowser about the capital city under President Trump and the planned renaming of Black Lives Matter Plaza. (Image credit: Alex Brandon)

Title: Driving while high is hard to detect. States are racing to find a good tool
Description: Police are experimenting with various methods to determine whether drivers are under the influence of marijuana, but unlike alcohol, a number of factors make that difficult to know with certainty. (Image credit: Kathryn Scott Osler)

Title: Benita Long disappeared. So why wasn't she added to this missing person database?
Description: A federally funded database helps track long-term, missing-person cases. Yet an NPR investigation finds that even in states legally required to use it, more than 2,000 people haven't been added. (Image credit: Jovelle Tamayo for NPR)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Mark Carney to become Canada's next prime minister, ICE arrests Palestinian activist who helped lead Columbia University protests, House Republicans unveil plan to fund government through September.

Title: Former Canadian diplomat Colin Robertson discusses strained Canada-U.S. relations
Description: Former Canadian diplomat Colin Robertson, now with the Canadian Global Affairs Institute, talks with NPR's Steve Inskeep about the strained relationship between Canada and the U.S.

Title: In show of unity, some 350,000 protesters gather in Mexico City
Description: Mexico has been a target of threats of potential military action and of new tariffs since Trump took office. Mexico's president called for rally in Mexico City, and some 350,000 people showed up.

Title: Deadliest phase of fentanyl crisis eases, as all states see recovery
Description: In some parts of the U.S. drug deaths have plunged to levels not seen since the fentanyl crisis exploded. Addiction experts say communities still face big challenges. (Image credit: Rachel Wisniewski for NPR)

Title: Experts say fentanyl crisis may be ending
Description: Fatal overdoses from fentanyl and other street drugs continue to plunge - and have now dropped from their peak in all 50 states.

Title: Hear the latest on a possible new ceasefire between Israel and Hamas
Description: A new ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas is likely in a matter of weeks, according to President Trump's hostage affairs envoy. Hear the latest updates on negotiations.

Title: ICE arrests Palestinian activist who helped lead Columbia University protests
Description: ICE arrested a Columbia University graduate student involved in campus protests over the war in Gaza. Mahmoud Khalil is a U.S. permanent resident. His attorney says he faces deportation.

Title: More than 1,300 Syrians killed in clashes and acts of revenge, monitoring group says
Description: A war monitoring group says clashes and revenge killings in Syria leave more than 1,000 dead

Title: Former central banker Mark Carney to be Canada's next prime minister
Description: In Canada, Mark Carney won the Liberal Party's leadership contest, and will replace outgoing Prime Minister Justin Trudeau. He's not fond of Trump suggesting that Canada become America's 51st state.

Title: ICE arrests Palestinian activist who helped lead Columbia University protests
Description: Mahmoud Khalil was inside his university-owned apartment Saturday night when several Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents entered and took him into custody. (Image credit: Ted Shaffrey)

Title: Surprise strike at Germany's Hamburg Airport affects more than 40,000 passengers
Description: The walkout, which reportedly took place with only about a half-hour advance notice, came before a broader series of preannounced strikes across 13 airports in Germany on Monday. (Image credit: Andreas Arnold)

Title: Playwright Athol Fugard, who chronicled apartheid and its aftermath, dies at 92
Description: The celebrated South African playwright was known for Blood Knot, The Road to Mecca and 'Master Harold'...and the Boys. He said his job was to make 'leaps out of my reality and into other realities.' (Image credit: John Minihan/Express/Hulton Archive)

Title: Mark Carney set to become Canada's new Prime Minister after Liberal party victory
Description: Carney, 59, will succeed Justin Trudeau, who announced in January that he would step down amid low approval ratings following a decade in office. (Image credit: Jason Franson)

Title: More than 1,300 Syrians killed in 72 hours amid clashes and acts of revenge
Description: A human rights group characterized the killings as executions and massacres, carried out in revenge against the Alawite community, which made up Assad's longtime base of support. (Image credit: Moawia Atras)

Title: Thousands of online scam workers are stuck in limbo in Myanmar
Description: NPR's Scott Detrow speaks with journalist Jan Camenzind Broomby about the thousands of people who are stuck in limbo after being caught in online scam centers in Myanmar but who can't return home.

Title: Trump rebuffed by Iran's leader after sending letter calling for nuclear negotiation
Description: Iran's UN mission says its open to limited talks over 'militarization' of its nuclear program (Image credit: AP)

Title: Pope Francis pens prayer thanking hospital staff, as he shows 'mild improvement'
Description: The Holy See Press Office said the pontiff has shown 'a good response to the therapies.' He was hospitalized on Feb. 14 for a case of bronchitis. (Image credit: Christopher Furlong)

Title: NPR investigation finds a widespread culture of abuse in federal court system
Description: An NPR investigation finds problems with the federal court system and a deep culture of fear about reporting judges for abusive behavior and sexual harassment.

Title: U.S. Secret Service says it shot a man near the White House after a confrontation
Description: A man who was brandishing a firearm in Washington, D.C., was shot by Secret Service officers near the White House on Sunday morning, the Secret Service said. (Image credit: Ron Edmonds)

Title: The Trump administration claims credit for a quiet border. The data shows otherwise
Description: The U.S.-Mexico border is quieter than it's been in years. Vice President Vance says the Trump administration deserves the credit, but migrant apprehensions have been falling for months.

Title: Cleveland Mayor Justin Bibb says Trump's 'America First' agenda is hurting the city
Description: NPR's Ayesha Rascoe speaks with Cleveland mayor Justin Bibb who argues that President Trump's budget cuts and funding freezes will hurt cities like his.

Title: This synagogue calls itself 'anti-Zionist.' Here's what that means in practice
Description: Tzedek Chicago calls itself anti-Zionist congregation, meaning it does not support a Jewish nation-state. (Image credit: Yonat Shimron)

Title: 60 years after Bloody Sunday in Alabama, elusive racial progress in Selma
Description: Events in Selma, Ala. six decades ago helped win support for the 1965 Voting Rights Act. Today local activists say they're still fighting stubborn segregation, poverty and gun violence. (Image credit: AFP)

Title: Trump DOJ's limits on FACE Act enforcement fuel concern from abortion providers
Description: New Justice Department leaders say past enforcement of the Freedom of Access to Clinic Entrances Act is 'the prototypical example' of what they call 'the weaponization of law enforcement.' (Image credit: Jon Cherry)

Title: New York governor declares state of emergency for brush fires on Long Island
Description: Fast-moving brush fires fanned by high winds burned through a large swath of land on New York's Long Island on Saturday, prompting the evacuation of a military base and the closure of a major highway. (Image credit: Steve Pfost)

Title: Experts warn that recent school shootings show growth in new radicalization pattern
Description: Some researchers say these recent attacks are examples of 'nonideological' terrorism — the result of several antisocial, decentralized, online networks coming together. (Image credit: Morry Gash)

Title: Intensifying violence tests new Syrian government
Description: In Syria, fighting is intensifying as clashes between Syrian security forces and gunmen loyal to former President Bashar Assad have left hundreds of people dead.

Title: One Texan's quest to create a state-wide hiking trail
Description: Texas isn't best seen from behind the steering wheel, but through shades, wearing hiking shoes on a walking trail. Now a Texan is making big strides on creating a walking trail called the X-Tx, stretching from the Louisiana border all the way to New Mexico, a 1,550-mile stroll that will be among the longest trails in the country. The trail will go through natural beauties from the Hill country/central Texas, Big Bend National Park and the Guadalupe mountains –highest point in the state-- surrounded by the Chihuahuan desert from west Texas. Texas Public Radio's Jack Morgan finds out how they plan to build the X-Tx. 4m piece + digital. Texas Public Radio's Jack Morgan. Target: week of 2/24. Alfredo edit.

Title: Vatican says hospitalized Pope Francis is showing 'gradual, slight improvement'
Description: The 88-year-old pontiff is responding well to the treatment for double pneumonia and has shown a 'gradual, slight improvement' in recent days, the Vatican said Saturday. (Image credit: Andrew Medichini)

Title: D.C.'s Black Lives Matter mural will be erased. Look back at the iconic street painting
Description: Over the past five years, Washington, D.C.'s iconic Black Lives Matter street painting has served as a powerful symbol of activism and a gathering place for joy and resistance. (Image credit: Kevin Dietsch)

Title: GOP unveils stopgap bill to avert a government shutdown. They may not have the votes.
Description: House Republicans released the text of a continuing resolution that would fund the government through Sept. 30. Now, passing it in a narrowly divided chamber is the next hurdle. (Image credit: Zayrha Rodriguez)

Title: Opinion: Thailand's deportation of Uyghurs to China has echoes of 10 years ago
Description: Thailand's recent deportations of Uyghurs to China have eerie parallels with a large deportation in 2015, in which the country bowed to Beijing, writes historian Jeffrey Wasserstrom. (Image credit: Chanakarn Laosarakham)

Title: States sue Trump administration over mass firings of federal employees
Description: The District of Columbia, Maryland and 18 other states have filed a lawsuit in federal court seeking the reinstatement of tens of thousands of federal employees fired since mid-February. (Image credit: Jim Watson)

Title: Montana's solution to rising property values: taxing wealthy, out-of-state homeowners
Description: As property values rise, Montana is seeking to cut taxes for most properties but raise them for out-of-state homeowners.

Title: Newly restored photos show the ruin of 'Bloody Sunday' in Selma on its 60th anniversary
Description: James 'Spider' Martin was assigned to photograph the protests in Alabama after civil rights activist Jimmie Lee Jackson was killed by state troopers. (Image credit: Spider Martin)

Title: Dairy farmers in Wisconsin see federal funding unfrozen as others are left waiting
Description: Dozens of Wisconsin dairy farmers are breathing a sigh of relief after federal funds they had been awarded were released and payments are now being promised. But anxiety persists for some. (Image credit: Chuck Quirmbach)

Title: A South Carolina prisoner is the first executed by a firing squad in 15 years
Description: A South Carolina man who killed his ex-girlfriend's parents with a baseball bat was executed by firing squad Friday, the first U.S. prisoner in 15 years to die by that method. (Image credit: Chris Carlson)

Title: Trump signs executive action targeting public service loan program
Description: The program forgives the loans of borrowers who work in public service. The executive action would exclude those who work for certain organizations. (Image credit: Brynn Anderson)

Title: Marco Rubio pivots to America First diplomacy
Description: It's been a little more than a week since Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy met with President Donald Trump in the Oval Office. Vice President JD Vance was in the meeting too. And Secretary of State Marco Rubio, the nation's top diplomat, sat on an Oval Office couch, mostly silent, as Trump and Vance berated the Ukrainian leader. Along the way, the president and vice president made it clear just how much of the established global order they are ready to upend. An order that for most of his career, Rubio has defended, and worked to help hold up. So what changed ...and what do those changes mean? For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org</a...

Title: Hong Kong company sells its ports in Panama, says it's business, not politics
Description: Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing's CK Hutchison Holdings sold its Panama ports business to a group of investors led by BlackRock. What does this episode tell us about Hong Kong today?

Title: The soundtrack to King Charles' life features music from Kylie Minogue
Description: King Charles III has admitted he is not impervious to a generational earworm like Kylie Minogue's 'Can't Get You Out of My Head,' after sharing a playlist that represents the soundtrack of his life. (Image credit: Central Press/Getty Images)

Title: Nablus soap gets UNESCO recognition in Israeli-occupied West Bank
Description: An ancient soap-making tradition in the Israeli-occupied West Bank has been added to the UNESCO list of Intangible Cultural Heritage. NPR visits one of the oldest soap factories in the city of Nablus.

Title: Trump administration cancels $400 million in federal dollars for Columbia University
Description: The administration said it was cancelling grants and other federal awards for Columbia for an alleged failure to protect Jewish students from antisemitism. (Image credit: Alex Kent)

Title: Gene Hackman died of heart disease, his wife died of hantavirus, authorities say
Description: Actor Gene Hackman died of heart disease a full week after his wife died from hantavirus in their New Mexico hillside home, authorities revealed Friday. (Image credit: Chris Pizzello)

Title: A Lagos community, destroyed in one day
Description: At least 9,000 people have been forcefully evicted from a riverside community in Nigeria's most populous city, Lagos. Like many waterfront communities across the city, it has faced multiple threats and been targeted by luxury real estate developers. (Image credit: Sunday Alamba/AP)

Title: President Trump brings back practice of detaining families together
Description: President Trump — and several other former presidents — also detained families during his first term in an effort to deter migration through the southern border. (Image credit: Veronica G. Cardenas/POOL)

Title: New research reveals ancient humans used animal bone tools much earlier than thought
Description: The handcrafted tools found in Tanzania were made 1.5 million years ago and were fashioned primarily from the bones of elephants and hippopotamuses. (Image credit: CSIC)

Title: The Dangerous Popularity of Skin Whitening Products in Nigeria
Description: In many parts of the world skin whitening is a major industry, but women in Nigeria have a particular fondness for creams and lotions that promise to lighten their skin. By one estimate, over 77% of women in the country have used such products. We go to Nigeria and learn that the effects of skin whiteners can be severe and many people who use them are unable to stop.

Title: A former Olympic snowboarder makes the FBI's Most Wanted list
Description: Ryan Wedding, a former Canadian Olympic snowboarder-turned-alleged-drug trafficker, 'went from shredding powder on the slopes at the Olympics to distributing powder cocaine,' the FBI says. (Image credit: Damian Dovarganes)

Title: Syria imposes curfew after its worst clashes since the Assad regime ouster
Description: Syria's new government sent in security reinforcements and imposed curfews on a coastal area after major clashes with fighters loyal to the deposed Syrian President Bashar al-Assad. (Image credit: Omar Albam)

Title: War heroes are among 26,000 images flagged for removal in Pentagon's DEI purge
Description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth had given the military until Wednesday to remove content highlighting diversity efforts following an executive order ending those programs across the government. (Image credit: Sgt. Tyler Main)

Title: A look at some of the creative ways companies try to dodge high tariffs
Description: Companies can try to avoid or minimize tariffs by requesting exemptions or legally reclassifying their products. Here's a look at some of the strategies that have worked in the past. (Image credit: Brandon Bell)

Title: Monthly jobs report to be released. And, the White House to host a crypto event
Description: The Labor Department will release the monthly jobs report card today, which is expected to show solid growth. But that's not the whole picture. And, the White House will host a cryptocurrency summit.

Title: Farmers strongly back Trump. A new trade war could test their loyalty
Description: American farmers have stood firmly behind President Trump even when his trade policies hurt them. The latest trade war, which could be even worse for their sector, promises to test those ties again. (Image credit: Joshua A. Bickel)

Title: Afghans in Pakistan awaiting U.S. resettlement are stuck in a treacherous limbo
Description: The Trump administration has halted the U.S. refugee program, Pakistan is taking steps to force Afghans out — and their lives may be at risk if they return to their own country. (Image credit: Betsy Joles for NPR)

Title: Trump says nobody has heard of Lesotho. Can you answer our quiz question about it?
Description: It was another action-packed week, with the Academy Awards, Mardi Gras and the president's address to Congress. Did you pay attention?

Title: Why VA mental health workers feel Elon Musk's emails are psychological warfare
Description: Mental health professionals with the Veterans Health Administration say the stress caused by Elon Musk's 'What did you do last week?' emails is hurting veterans' care. (Image credit: Deagreez/iStockphoto/Getty Images)

Title: Why the Trump administration is negotiating directly with Hamas
Description: Why is the U.S. negotiating with Hamas, in conflict with policy to not negotiate with U.S.-designated terrorist groups? NPR speaks with Brian Katulis, senior fellow at the Middle East Institute.

Title: Uncertainty grows surrounding the ceasefire in Gaza between Israel and Hamas
Description: The first phase of the ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas ended with no agreement on what comes next. President Trump is demanding that Hamas immediately free all of its remaining hostages.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Labor Department to release monthly jobs report card, President Trump to speak to cryptocurrency founders and investors at the White House, uncertainty grows over ceasefire between Israel and Hamas.

Title: Georgia factory resumes peanut paste production for starving children overseas
Description: Lifesaving peanut paste for malnourished children is being produced again at a Georgia factory after the Trump administration reversed course on a canceled USAID contract.

Title: How a measles outbreak overwhelmed a small west Texas town
Description: There's an unusual health scare in far west Texas right now. The disease that's spreading, the measles, was thought to have been a thing of the past. The CDC declared it eliminated from the United States in 2000. But health officials have now confirmed some 80 cases in Gaines County and they expect the number to rise. This part of Texas is home to a large Mennonite population. And a lot of those folks shun vaccinations, making them vulnerable to the disease, which is highly contagious. Gaines County had the highest unvaccinated rate in Texas this school year at 18 percent, according to state health data. Some health officials worry that the politicization of vaccines has led even more parents to forgo vaccinating their young children, leading to outbreaks like this one. And this community ...

Description: Nearly five years after George Floyd's murder by a Minneapolis police officer, the force is taking lessons from Los Angeles police who worked through the aftermath of the 1992 beating of Rodney King.

Title: If you see something (woke), say something
Description: Code Switch's Gene Demby looks into the Department of Education's new end-DEI portal that asks Americans to narc on their local public schools.

Title: Unexploded WWII bomb in Paris halts Eurostar travel to London
Description: The French transport minister said traffic would be ''strongly disrupted'' throughout the day with only limited service resuming in the afternoon, and urged travelers to postpone their trips. (Image credit: Christophe Ena)

Title: Five takeaways: China's foreign minister slams Trump's 'two-faced' policies
Description: China's top foreign policy official addressed the escalating trade war with the U.S. and promoted China as an 'anchor' on the global stage as America retreats from international involvement. (Image credit: Ng Han Guan)

Title: Walgreens agrees to be acquired by private equity firm for almost $10 billion
Description: A buyout to take the drugstore chain private would give it more flexibility to make changes to improve its business without worrying about Wall Street's reaction. (Image credit: Gene J. Puskar)

Title: Court orders South Korean President Yoon released from jail
Description: The decision would allow Yoon to stand his criminal trial while not being physically detained. The court is expected to rule soon on whether to uphold his impeachment or remove him from office. (Image credit: Ahn Young-joon)

Title: SpaceX loses contact with spacecraft during Starship mega rocket test flight
Description: Nearly two months after an explosion sent flaming debris raining down on the Turks and Caicos, SpaceX launched another mammoth Starship rocket but lost contact minutes into the test flight. (Image credit: Eric Gay)

Title: The European Union Decides to Rearm
Description: Leaders of the European Union have voted to approve a plan to dramatically increase defense spending. The move is a reaction to the U.S. reducing its support for Ukraine in the war against Russia's invasion. We go to Brussels to understand the ramifications. And we hear what the series of recent developments in the relationship between the U.S. and Ukraine could mean for peace talks with Russia. (Image credit: HATIM KAGHAT)

Title: When it comes to the economy, it's all about uncertainty
Description: Like a lot of economists, Mark Zandi, with Moody's Analytics, thinks President Trump's across-the-board tariffs are a bad idea. Saying, 'Tariffs, broad-based tariffs, are a real problem for the economy.'But Zandi says – it's not just the tariffs themselves that are the problem, it's the uncertainty created by Trump's rollout. Trump threatened 25% Tariffs on Canada and Mexico would start in February. They were paused at the 11th hour, only to eventually go into effect this week.On Thursday Trump announced the new tariffs would be paused for most products, but potentially only until April 2.Meanwhile tariffs on China snapped into place in February, and then doubled, to 20%.What happens next is anyone's guess. Businesses have been optimistic about the e...

Title: California man charged after Lego larceny worth $25,000
Description: The heists occurred in several California counties, where the alleged thief would load his shopping cart with the expensive building toys and disappear into the parking lot in a matter of minutes. (Image credit: Dan Kitwood)

Title: Democracy-promoting organization sues the Trump administration over withheld funds
Description: President Ronald Reagan laid the rhetorical foundations for the National Endowment for Democracy in a 1982 speech to the British Parliament. Support for its creation in Congress was bipartisan. (Image credit: Fox Photos/Hulton Archive)

Title: At a housewares expo in Chicago, talk keeps turning to price hikes from tariffs
Description: The Inspired Home Show in Chicago draws housewares industry insiders from all over the country to network and show off their latest gadgets. This year, they're making plans to cope with tariffs.

Title: South Korean fighter jets drop bombs in the wrong place, injuring 8 people
Description: The air force said the jets were taking part in a drill with the U.S. military in Pocheon, a city close to the border with North Korea, when they dropped bombs just outside a firing range. (Image credit: Yonhap)

Title: Fighter jets accidentally drop bombs during exercises, injuring 8 South Koreans
Description: The air force said the jets were taking part in a drill with the U.S. military in Pocheon, a city close to the border with North Korea, when they dropped bombs just outside a firing range. (Image credit: /)

Title: Palestinians freed in the ceasefire say Israeli forces harass them and their families
Description: Several Palestinian prisoners and detainees freed during this ceasefire deal have been harassed by Israeli forces after their release, their homes raided or their family members arrested. (Image credit: Afif H. Amireh for NPR)

Title: Steve Carell announces that a charity will fund proms for students affected by LA fires
Description: The children's organization, Alice's Kids, will cover the costs for approximately 800 students to enjoy prom night. (Image credit: Dia Dipasupil)

Title: Layoffs and potential closures of key facilities raise worries about NOAA's future
Description: The Trump administration may end leases for some of NOAA's offices while the agency terminates several advisory committees at the important weather and climate agency. (Image credit: Joe Raedle)

Title: Automakers granted relief from tariffs. And, fired USDA workers return to work
Description: President Trump announced a one-month reprieve from import tariffs for automakers after he imposed them on Canada and Mexico. And, thousands of fired USDA workers return to work today.

Title: As Canadians cancel trips due to Trump, the U.S. tourism industry could lose billions
Description: The Trump administration's attacks on its northern neighbor have been met with confusion and anger by some Canadians who are now cancelling their trips to the U.S. in protest. (Image credit: Patrick T. Fallon)

Title: How does the U.S. federal workforce compare with those in other countries?
Description: President Trump's administration has fired more than 20,000 federal workers. How does the federal workforce compare with those of other countries? (Image credit: Kevin Dietsch)

Title: State Supreme Court races can be costly, competitive and combative. Why?
Description: Wisconsin is on track to break spending records once again in a high court contest that's at times turned heated. But these races weren't always like this. (Image credit: Angela Major)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: EU leaders to hold emergency meeting on Ukraine support and Russian threats, Trump grants automakers one-month reprieve from tariffs, nearly 6,000 USDA workers fired by Trump ordered back to work.

Title: European Union leaders hold emergency summit on Ukraine support
Description: European Union leaders are expected to discuss rapidly increasing defense budgets. There's new urgency after President Trump paused military supplies and intelligence sharing with Ukraine. (Image credit: Geert Vanden Wijngaert)

Title: EU leaders to hold emergency summit on Ukraine support, Russian threats to continent
Description: EU leaders are gathering for an emergency summit to coordinate support for Ukraine and to protect the continent from Russian threats. They are expected to discuss rapidly increasing defense budgets.

Title: What peace talks between Russia, Ukraine and the U.S. might look like
Description: What could peace talks between Russia, Ukraine and the U.S. look like? NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Bob Hamilton, head of Eurasia research at the Foreign Policy Research Institute.

Title: North Carolina nonprofit helping dispel panic and rumors amid immigration crackdown
Description: President Trump demands cities and states cooperate with immigration enforcement. In immigrant communities, that's led to panic and many rumors. A North Carolina nonprofit is helping dispel them.

Title: Israel threatens intervention in Syrian capital Damascus due to unrest there
Description: A suburb of Damascus is at the center of the new Syrian government's struggle for control. Now, Israel is threatening to intervene due to unrest there, turning this into an international incident.

Title: Rural Alaskan schools are crumbling as the state fails to provide funding to fix them
Description: Rural schools in Alaska are plagued with health and safety issues. The state has failed for nearly two decades to provide the funding needed to fix them, despite repeated requests.

Title: How tax cuts on Social Security benefits would impact the program's longevity
Description: President Trump has promised again to cut taxes on Social Security benefits. NPR asks the Committee for a Responsible Budget's Marc Goldwein about the potential impact on the program's longevity.

Title: Lesotho officials shocked by Trump's remarks that 'nobody' has heard of their country
Description: Government officials in the small African country of Lesotho were shocked by President Trump's dismissive remarks that 'nobody has ever heard' of their country.

Title: Iowan with a transgender child reacts to state's elimination of protections
Description: Iowa eliminated anti-discrimination protections for transgender people from its civil rights law. NPR's Leila Fadel talks to Matt McIver, an Iowan with a transgender child.

Title: Ukrainian Americans deeply concerned about the U-turn in U.S.-Ukraine relations
Description: Philadelphia and parts of New Jersey have some of the country's largest populations of Ukrainian Americans. Many are deeply concerned about the turn in U.S.-Ukraine relations.

Title: Trump prepares order dismantling the Education Department
Description: The draft executive action, obtained by NPR, acknowledges the department and its signature responsibilities were created by Congress, and cannot legally be altered without congressional approval. (Image credit: Jose Luis Magana/AP)

Title: Trump administration can remove head of federal watchdog agency, appeals court rules
Description: A U.S. appeals court has sided with the administration in allowing the removal of Hampton Dellinger from the Office of Special Counsel. The office investigates actions like whistleblower retaliation. (Image credit: Win McNamee)

Title: Trump says tariffs will help stop fentanyl. Many of his claims on the crisis are untrue
Description: Trump continues to link his tariffs to fentanyl and overdose deaths — in his speech to Congress and on social media. But many of his statements about the fentanyl crisis aren't factual.

Title: A CDC worker was fired. Then unexpectedly got her job back. She's not sure what to do
Description: CDC Public Health Associate Bri McNulty, who talked to NPR about being summarily fired last week, got an email that she had her job back. In the meantime, McNulty got a job offer at Penn State.

Title: Nobel Peace Prize winner Lech Walesa condemns President Trump's treatment of Zelenskyy
Description: Nobel Peace Prize winner Lech Walesa expresses fear and distaste at how Trump treats Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy.

Title: A look into Iran's economic woes
Description: President Trump wants to squeeze Iran's economy by reducing its crude oil exports to zero. But Iran's economy has already been in freefall for months.

Title: What to know about Lesotho, the country Trump said 'nobody has ever heard of'
Description: President Trump defended his humanitarian aid cuts to countries around the globe, including one nation he joked 'nobody has ever heard of.' Here are some facts about the African nation of Lesotho. (Image credit: Themba Hadebe)

Title: By the numbers: Does LeBron James' new points record shake up the GOAT debate?
Description: LeBron James has been so good for so long, there's a famous running joke about when he might slow down. At age 40, where does his 50,000 career points record put him in the GOAT debate? (Image credit: Sean M. Haffey)

Title: In a first, the 2026 World Cup final will include a halftime show
Description: Like the Super Bowl mid-game spectaculars, the 2026 final game slated to take place at MetLife Stadium in New Jersey will include the World Cup's very first halftime show. (Image credit: Richard Heathcote)

Title: Going Back in Time to Soviet Central Asia's Boogie Nights
Description: Today we take a break from the serious and often depressing international news beat to bring you the sound's of Soviet Central Asia in the 1970's and 80's. Our Moscow correspondent introduces us to an anthology of songs that came out of a record factory in Tashkent documenting a wide variety of music from the silk road in that time period.

Title: In a policy shift, U.S. and Hamas say they're in direct talks on hostages
Description: A Hamas official tells NPR that the United States has held direct talks with the Palestinian militant group over the release of several American-Israeli dual citizens taken hostage during the Oct. 7, 2023, attacks in Israel. (Image credit: Eyad Baba)

Title: Dozens of Canadians are charged for scamming American grandparents out of $21 million
Description: The 25 Canadians are accused of calling seniors in over 40 states, pretending to be their grandchildren and asking for bail money. Authorities warn such scams are getting increasingly sophisticated. (Image credit: Bernd Weißbrod)

Title: More than 5,000 USDA workers fired by Trump ordered back to work for now
Description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture must temporarily reinstate more than 5,000 probationary employees fired since Feb. 13, according to a ruling by the Merit Systems Protection Board. (Image credit: Saul Loeb)

Title: Meet the Syrians behind the music that inspired a revolution
Description: Syrian soccer player Abdel Basset al-Sarout became the poster child for the Syrian revolution with his iconic protest anthems. In death, he has become its saint. But he didn't do it alone. (Image credit: Yahya Nemah for NPR)

Title: Supreme Court upholds lower court order to force USAID to pay contractors
Description: In an order, the justices left in place a lower court order that so far has only required the Trump administration to pay contractors for foreign aid work that has already been completed — roughly $2 billion. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: Takeaways from Trump's address to Congress. And, China projects confidence in economy
Description: President Trump delivered a partisan address to a joint session of Congress last night, boasting about his accomplishments from the first six weeks. And, China projects confidence in its economy. (Image credit: Win McNamee)

Title: What went wrong? Israel's spy agency lists failures in preventing Oct. 7 attack
Description: Israel's domestic security agency had Hamas' battle plans for the Oct. 7, 2023 attacks but didn't take them seriously. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu deflected responsibility for the failure. (Image credit: Amir Levy)

Title: God walks with us through the ashes.' A poignant Ash Wednesday after LA wildfires
Description: On Ash Wednesday, Christians hear the words 'Remember that you are dust and to dust you shall return.' Those words ring differently for many whose churches and homes burned in the Los Angeles fires. (Image credit: Jason DeRose)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: A recap of President Trump's address to a joint session of Congress, Trump touts success of some of his immigration policies during address, and China opens its annual session of parliament.

Title: Virginia Sen. Tim Kaine plans to force Republicans to vote on Trump's Canada tariffs
Description: Republicans are 'nervous' about President Trump's tariffs raising prices, says Democratic Sen. Tim Kaine of Virginia. He plans to force a vote in the Senate on them soon. (Image credit: Nathan Posner)

Title: Central Asian Soviet-era pop music anthology dislays the region's vast diversity

Title: As Washington changes course on Ukraine, Taiwan wonders about its own fate

Title: Mexico and Canada React to U.S. Tariffs; Ukraine Adjusts to Losing U.S. Support

And the Trump administration has announce it is suspending military aid to Ukraine. Our correspondent in Kyiv says Ukraine is figuring out how it can continue despite losing support from the country's single most important ally.

Title: How Trump's foreign policy is reshaping the world order
Description: After the Trump-Zelenskyy blow-up on Friday, European leaders held emergency talks in London to put together a roadmap to peace. Then, on Tuesday, European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen announced a proposal called ReArm Europe. The roughly $840 billion plan would quickly build up defense budgets in Europe. Meanwhile, the U.S. seems to continue to align itself with Russia. President Trump is upending the U.S.-led order that has dominated global politics for the better part of a century. Title: The political power of the pope

Much of the world has spent the last two weeks focused on Pope Francis' health. And the reason why has as much to do with the fact that he's a powerful geopolitical force as it does with the fact he's a key religious figure. Title: Trump's alienation of Europe has China 'delighted,' says former U.S. ambassador
Description: President Trump is threatening to put more tariffs on China. But the U.S. rival is in a better position to ride out American economic retaliation, says former U.S. Ambassador to China Winston Lord. (Image credit: Susan Walsh)
